deliberation: Checked for metaphorical uses (e.g., 'go down,' 'house of the king') or personification. Here 'go down to the house of the king of Judah' is best read as a literal spatial movement to the royal palace; no clear figurative device stands out.
Considered whether 'throne of David' and 'gates' are literal or figurative. The phrase 'throne of David' functions as a dynastic symbol, a metonymy for royal authority in David’s line.

instances.english_text: you who sit on the throne of David
posture: affirmation of Davidic legitimacy even in rebuke
instances.explanation: The 'throne of David' stands metonymically for the Davidic kingship and its authority, not merely the physical chair.

deliberation: Most commands are literal ethical injunctions. Two phrases use conventional Hebrew figurative language: 'from the hand of the oppressor' (hand as power) and 'shed innocent blood' (blood as life).

instances.english_text: rescue from the defrauder anyone who is robbed (lit. 'from the hand of the oppressor')
target: the oppressor’s control over the victim
vehicle: bodily part as symbol of power
ground: ability to grasp, control, and harm
instances.explanation: The 'hand' of the oppressor is a metonymy and idiom for his power or control, from which the robbed must be rescued.

instances.english_text: do not shed the blood of the innocent
vehicle: vital fluid as stand-in for life
ground: blood represents life and its loss
instances.explanation: Here 'blood' stands metonymically for the life of the innocent; 'shedding blood' is a fixed idiom for killing.

deliberation: The verse promises literal royal prosperity—kings entering the palace gates on chariots and horses. While vivid, it can be read straightforwardly as concrete description of royal processions rather than a distinct metaphor.

Considered whether 'this house shall become a ruin' is figurative. Given the context of siege and destruction, it naturally refers to the palace’s literal devastation. No clear additional figurative layer is required.

Here the 'house of the king of Judah' is likened to regions (Gilead, Lebanon) and then threatened with becoming a wilderness and uninhabited towns. These are extended metaphors for the palace/royal house’s former glory and coming desolation.

instances.english_text: You are as Gilead to Me
posture: recalling former favor and value prior to judgment
instances.explanation: The palace of Judah is metaphorically identified with Gilead, a rich and desirable region, to stress its former excellence in God’s sight.

instances.english_text: the summit (head) of Lebanon
vehicle: highest part of famed cedar-covered mountain
posture: acknowledgment of exalted status before announcing its reversal
instances.explanation: Calling the palace 'the summit of Lebanon' figuratively portrays its exalted and splendid status using Lebanon’s famous heights.

instances.hebrew_text: אִם־לֹא אֲשִׁיתְךָ מִדְבָּר עָרִים לֹא נוֹשָׁבוּ
instances.english_text: I will make you a desert, uninhabited towns
target: royal palace/house (and by extension the royal city)
posture: threat of radical judgment and reversal of fortune
instances.explanation: The palace is threatened with becoming 'a desert, uninhabited towns,' a metaphor for complete desolation and depopulation.

deliberation: The verse continues the forest/palace imagery with 'your choicest cedars,' echoing Lebanon and cedar imagery in the context. Although it can refer literally to cedar beams of the palace, it also functions as a symbol of royal luxury to be destroyed.

instances.english_text: They shall cut down your choicest cedars
target: the palace’s finest features and royal splendor
posture: announcement of the stripping away of luxury as judgment
instances.explanation: The 'choicest cedars' stand metonymically for the palace’s most luxurious elements, whose destruction signifies the fall of royal splendor.

deliberation: The nations literally 'pass by this city' and ask a question. 'Great city' is an evaluative epithet rather than a clear hyperbole. No distinct metaphor, simile, or other figure is necessary for the sense.
Straightforward explanation of the cause of judgment—forsaking the covenant and serving other gods. No special figurative vehicles are used beyond standard theological terminology.

Looked for euphemistic or metaphorical use of 'the one going' and the weeping language. The contrast between death and exile is rhetorical but expressed with ordinary terms for weeping and going; no stable idiomatic metaphor clearly distinct from the literal meaning.
Narrates about Shallum who went out and will not return. The language of going out and not returning is literal in the context of exile. No clear figurative expression detected.
States that he will die in the place of exile and not see the land again. These are literal predictions, without metaphorical or personifying language.

While 'building his house with injustice' could have a secondary sense of building a regime, in context it addresses actual construction projects using unpaid labor. The verse functions as literal social critique, not as an independent metaphor.
Describes literal architectural ambitions: a large house, spacious upper rooms, windows, cedar paneling, vermilion. These are concrete details rather than figurative vehicles.

Key question is the phrase 'compete in cedar,' where cedar stands for royal luxury. 'Cedar' here functions metonymically as a symbol of extravagant kingship, contrasted with the just rule of the father.

instances.english_text: Do you think you are more a king because you compete in cedar?
target: the king’s claim to true kingship and status
ground: cedar symbolizes opulence and royal show
posture: ironical challenge to superficial markers of kingship
instances.explanation: To 'compete in cedar' is an idiomatic-metonymic way to speak of competing in ostentatious royal luxury, as if that made one truly a king.

deliberation: Defines 'knowing' GOD as doing justice for the poor and needy. This is theological but not expressed via an additional image or vehicle (no metaphor like 'path,' 'light,' etc.); the verse is conceptual rather than figuratively imagistic.
Eyes and heart are said to be 'on' greed, bloodshed, and oppression. Here 'eyes' and 'heart' function as metonymy/synecdoche for the whole inner orientation and desire of the king.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי אֵין עֵינֶיךָ וְלִבְּךָ כִּי אִם־עַל־בִּצְעֶךָ
instances.english_text: But your eyes and your mind (heart) are only on ill-gotten gains
target: the king’s inner motives and desires
vehicle: sense organ and inner organ as symbols of attention and will
ground: where one looks and what one’s heart focuses on indicate desire
posture: condemnation of greed and violence at the core of royal character
instances.explanation: The physical 'eyes' and 'heart' stand metonymically for the king’s focus and will, depicting his whole inner orientation as fixed on gain and violence.

deliberation: The verse quotes stereotypical mourning cries ('Ah, brother!', etc.). These are formulaic expressions of lament but not metaphorical in themselves; the point is that such laments will not be uttered. No distinct figurative vehicle is central here.

The 'burial of a donkey' is a vivid comparison for disgraceful lack of proper burial. It is a metaphorical/idiomatic way to describe a shameful end rather than a technical description of a burial rite.

instances.english_text: He shall have the burial of a donkey
target: the king’s dishonorable death and treatment of his corpse
vehicle: disposal of an unclean working animal
ground: lack of honor, care, or mourning; being cast out
posture: severe denigration of the king’s end as a form of judgment
instances.explanation: To say he will have 'the burial of a donkey' metaphorically and idiomatically depicts a shameful, unceremonious end, like an animal carcass dragged out and dumped.

deliberation: Judah (feminine 'you') is told to climb Lebanon, Bashan, and Abarim and cry because 'all your lovers are crushed.' The nation is personified as a woman, and 'lovers' is a metaphor for political allies.

instances.english_text: Climb Lebanon and cry out, raise your voice in Bashan, cry out from Abarim
target: the nation/people of Judah (often embodied as Jerusalem)
vehicle: a woman moving over mountains and crying out
ground: the city/nation cannot literally climb and cry; it is spoken of as a single woman in distress
posture: summons to lament over coming disaster
instances.explanation: Judah is personified as a woman commanded to go up on high places and wail, dramatizing the nation’s coming grief.

instances.english_text: For all your lovers are crushed
target: Judah’s foreign allies or political patrons
ground: intimate but illicit relationship, dependence, and betrayal
improper reliance on foreign powers as on illicit lovers
posture: condemning Judah’s alliances as adulterous loves now destroyed
instances.explanation: The foreign allies on whom Judah relied are metaphorically called 'lovers,' turning political dependence into the picture of illicit romantic relationships that end in ruin.

deliberation: Phrase 'this is your way from your youth' conceptualizes behavior as a 'way' or path, a common Hebrew metaphor for life-conduct.

instances.english_text: That was your way ever since your youth
target: Judah’s habitual pattern of refusing to listen
ground: a path is something consistently followed; a lifestyle is something habitually practiced
instances.explanation: Calling disobedience 'your way' uses the common Hebrew metaphor of a 'way' or path for a settled course of life and behavior.

deliberation: Three figurative elements: (1) 'shepherds' as a metaphor for leaders, (2) 'wind' acting destructively on them (personification/imagistic metaphor), and (3) again 'lovers' as a metaphor for foreign allies.

instances.english_text: All your shepherds
vehicle: animal herders who guide and protect flocks
ground: shepherds lead, protect, and are responsible for sheep; leaders do (or should do) the same for people
instances.explanation: The leaders of Judah are metaphorically called 'shepherds,' drawing on the common biblical figure of rulers as caretakers of a flock.

instances.hebrew_text: תִּרְעֶה־רוּחַ (cf. Eng. 'shall be devoured by the wind')
instances.english_text: shall be devoured by the wind
target: the security and existence of Judah’s leaders
ground: wind can sweep away and destroy; invading powers or divine judgment remove leaders irresistibly
instances.explanation: The 'wind' is personified and metaphorically portrayed as devouring or driving away the shepherds, symbolizing the destructive force of judgment/exile.

instances.english_text: and your lovers shall go into captivity
target: Judah’s foreign allies or friendly powers
ground: intimate, chosen relationships reflecting attachment and misplaced trust
improper affection for foreign powers rather than for God
posture: exposing alliances as adulterous loves now humiliated
instances.explanation: Again 'lovers' metaphorically denotes Judah’s foreign allies, whose captivity underscores the folly of trusting them.

deliberation: Two main images: (1) Judah/royal house depicted as dwelling in Lebanon and nesting in cedars—a personified, birdlike metaphor for secure luxury; (2) suffering likened to the pains of a woman giving birth.

instances.english_text: You who dwell in Lebanon, nestled among the cedars
target: the royal house / Jerusalem / Judah in luxurious security
vehicle: dwelling in Lebanon, nesting in cedars
a bird or woman securely lodged in tall cedars on Lebanon
ground: height, security, and luxury; cedar imagery echoes palace building
posture: ironically highlighting false security before disaster
instances.explanation: Judah is personified and metaphorically portrayed as living high in Lebanon, like one 'nested in the cedars'—a picture of lofty, luxurious security soon to be shattered.

instances.english_text: pains come upon you, travail as in childbirth
target: the anguish Judah/royal house will experience in judgment
ground: intense, unavoidable, escalating pain leading to a crisis
instances.explanation: Judah’s coming anguish is compared explicitly to the travail of a woman in childbirth, emphasizing the intensity and inevitability of the suffering.

deliberation: The conditional 'if Coniah were a signet ring on My right hand, from there I would tear you off' is a clear metaphor: signet ring symbolizes cherished authority and closeness, yet even from there he would be removed.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי אִם־יִהְיֶה כׇּנְיָהוּ ... חוֹתָם עַל־יַד יְמִינִי כִּי מִשָּׁם אֶתְּקֶנְךָּ
instances.english_text: if you, O King Coniah ... were a signet on My right hand, I would tear you off even from there
target: King Coniah’s status and relationship to God
vehicle: signet ring on the right hand
precious royal seal worn by the owner
ground: a signet signifies intimate possession, authority, and honor, yet can be removed
both value and the owner’s freedom to discard
posture: emphasizing the certainty and radical nature of divine rejection
instances.explanation: Coniah is metaphorically likened to a signet ring—an honored, intimate possession—yet God declares He would still tear him off, stressing total rejection despite any former favor.

deliberation: Two conventional Hebrew idioms appear: being given 'into the hand' of someone (hand as power) and enemies who 'seek your life' (seeking life = trying to kill).

instances.hebrew_text: וּנְתַתִּיךָ בְּיַד מְבַקְשֵׁי נַפְשֶׁךָ ... וּבְיַד נְבוּכַדְרֶאצַּר ... וּבְיַד הַכַּשְׂדִּים
instances.english_text: I will deliver you into the hands of those who seek your life ... into the hand of King Nebuchadrezzar ... and into the hand of the Chaldeans
target: the control exerted by Coniah’s enemies over him
vehicle: bodily organ used to grasp and hold
ground: hands grasp and hold; being in someone’s hand = under their control
posture: depicting complete subjugation as divine judgment
instances.explanation: The recurring phrase 'into the hand of' is an idiomatic metonymy for falling under the power and control of enemies.

instances.english_text: those who seek your life
ground: to 'seek someone’s life' is to aim at killing them, not merely desiring their presence
posture: stressing the lethal intent of the enemies God uses as instruments
instances.explanation: The phrase 'seek your life' is a fixed idiom meaning 'to try to kill you,' highlighting the deadly intentions of these enemies.

deliberation: God says, 'I will hurl you and the mother who bore you into another land.' The verb of violent throwing treats people like objects to be flung away—a metaphor for forcible exile and rejection.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהֵטַלְתִּי אֹתְךָ וְאֶת־אִמְּךָ ... עַל הָאָרֶץ אַחֶרֶת
instances.english_text: I will hurl you and the mother who bore you into another land
target: Coniah and his mother’s forcible deportation
vehicle: hurling (throwing) an object onto a land
ground: objects hurled are forcibly, contemptuously displaced; so are these people in exile
posture: emphasizes the violence and contempt of the coming exile
instances.explanation: Using the verb 'hurl' for sending them into another land metaphorically depicts their exile as a violent, contemptuous throwing away.

deliberation: The idiom 'they lift up their soul to return there' uses 'soul' and 'lifting' metaphorically to express intense yearning for the land.

instances.hebrew_text: עַל־הָאָרֶץ אֲשֶׁר־הֵם מְנַשְּׂאִים אֶת־נַפְשָׁם לָשׁוּב שָׁם
instances.english_text: the land that they yearn (lit. 'lift up their soul') to come back to
target: the exiles’ intense longing for the homeland
vehicle: raising one’s inner self toward something
ground: lifting up implies directing and elevating one’s inner being toward an object of desire
posture: underscores deep, frustrated desire to return
instances.explanation: To 'lift up the soul' toward the land is an idiomatic metaphor for passionately yearning to return home.

deliberation: Central figure: Coniah is compared to a despised shattered pot, a vessel no one wants. This extended cookware/pottery metaphor highlights his rejection and uselessness.

instances.hebrew_text: הַעֶצֶב נִבְזֶה נָפוּץ הָאִישׁ הַזֶּה כׇּנְיָהוּ אִם־כְּלִי אֵין חֵפֶץ בּוֹ
instances.english_text: Is this man Coniah a despised broken pot, a vessel no one wants?
target: Coniah’s status and value in God’s and people’s eyes
ground: a shattered pot is useless and discarded; so Coniah is viewed as worthless and rejected
posture: emphatic denunciation of the king’s worth and future
instances.explanation: Coniah is metaphorically portrayed as a shattered, despised pot that no one desires, stressing his complete rejection and lack of future usefulness.

deliberation: The land is addressed directly and told to 'hear the word of the LORD.' This is personification of the land as a listener and respondent to God.

instances.english_text: O land, land, land, hear the word of the LORD!
target: the land of Judah (and by extension its inhabitants)
vehicle: land as a hearer addressed directly
ground: only persons 'hear' and obey; treating land as hearer dramatizes the address to the whole covenant environment
posture: solemn, urgent summons to attend to God’s word
instances.explanation: The land is personified as if it could listen and respond to God’s word, heightening the gravity of the proclamation to all creation associated with Judah.

deliberation: The command to 'write this man childless' is not strictly literal, since Coniah had offspring; it is a legal-metaphorical, somewhat hyperbolic way of declaring him dynastically cut off—no son will prosper on David’s throne.

instances.english_text: Record this man as without succession (childless)
vehicle: legal record of having no offspring
ground: to be childless in royal terms is to have no heirs to continue one’s line or office
posture: formal pronouncement of irreversible dynastic judgment
instances.explanation: To 'write this man childless' is a legal metaphor and hyperbole for declaring that, as far as the throne is concerned, he effectively has no heirs—none of his offspring will sit on David’s throne.
